title: Argentina handed red card just 18 minutes into England clash after brutal Owen Farrell hit
text:
Owen Farrell was tackled high by Tomas Lavanini to earn a red card (Picture: Getty)

Argentina’s efforts to upset England at the Rugby World Cup were hit by a hammer blow in the first 20 minutes when Tomas Lavanini was sent off.

The Pumas had taken an early lead through the boot of Benjamin Urdapilleta but were pegged back by Jonny May who went over in the corner for his 25th international try.

Owen Farrell missed the kick so Argentina remained just two points behind and after an early scuffle inside the England 22, the game was starting to bubble as a contest.

However, Lavanini overstepped the line and hit England’s captain in the head to earn a red card.

He's OFF 🔴 Argentina down to 14 as Tomas Lavanini is red carded for a high tackle on guess who? Farrell again…@Nigelrefowens explains the decision #RWC2019 #ENGvARG pic.twitter.com/IX4im3CAk8 — ITV Rugby (@ITVRugby) October 5, 2019

Advertisement

Advertisement

Referee Nigel Owens initially reacted to the tackle by telling the Television Match Official (TMO) that there was ‘no foul play for me’ and allowing the game to continue.

But when play stopped a few seconds later, he came back to investigate the incident further with the help of the TMO and slow-motion replay.

Upon review, Owens changed his mind about the nature of the tackle and the punishment he would dish out.

‘Clear foul play, clear contact with the head,’ Owens told the TMO over his microphone.

At half-time, former England captain Lawrence Dallaglio, speaking as an ITV pundit, said: ‘It’s a dangerous challenge and a definite red card.

‘It’s a red card all day long.’

Referee Nigel Owens felt he had no option but to send off the Argentine lock (Picture: Getty)

World Rugby have recently changed the rules by which referees decide how to punish high tackles in an effort to reduce the number of concussions.

The framework means players are more likely to be punished by a yellow or red card with contact to the head almost always likely to result in the tackler leaving the field.

Mitigating circumstances such as the ball-carrier dipping his head or falling down are considered but Owens decided there was ‘not enough mitigation in my view to avoid a red card’.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Lavanini became the fifth player of the tournament to be shown a red card – the record for the tournament had already been broken when Andrea Lovotti was dismissed for Italy against South Africa yesterday.

The Argentinian second row will go down in history as the 18th man to be sent off during a Rugby World Cup but only the second Puma with the first Pedro Sporleder way back in 1991.
